MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Jobsearch Programme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the staff resources which have been allocated to the Jobsearch programme; the grades of those involved; and from where they have been redeployed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The involvement of the Department of Labour and the Manpower agencies in the Jobsearch programme relates to the following activities: 150,000 persons on the live register to be interviewed; 40,000 to be offered manpower opportunities; 12,000 to be placed on Jobsearch courses.

MainHeading.P: The interviews of those on the live register are being carried out by the National Manpower Service with its own staff supplemented by 50 persons redeployed from AnCO and two from CERT. Eighteen clerical back-up staff have also been redeployed to the NMS, 12 of whom are from AnCO, two from CERT and four from YEA.
The grades of the redeployed staff from AnCO vary from Grade 6 (divisional manager) to Grade 14 (clerk typist). The majority are in the training adviser and executive assistant grades.
As regards CERT and the YEA, the regional staff are mainly in the clerical grade but also include an administrative officer and a training adviser.

The 40,000 manpower opportunities, involving places on training courses and employment schemes, as well as job vacancies, and the work experience programme, are being provided by the responsible agencies by redeployment of their own staff. The main agencies involved are the National Manpower Service and AnCO.

The Jobsearch courses are being organised by AnCO using as tutors staff redeployed from within the organisation. All told, 102 staff have been redeployed ranging from Grade 5 (regional manager) to Grade 11 (executive assistant). The majority of the staff are from the training adviser grade.
Overall monitoring of the Department of Labour involvement in the Jobsearch programme is being carried out within existing Departmental staff allocations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Network for Jobs Group.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the decision which the Teamwork Monitoring Committee reached on the proposals from the Network for Jobs Group at the June and September 1986, meetings respectively; if he will confirm that at no stage did the monitoring committee request that five separate applications on each project be supplied in order to satisfy themselves that the work involved in each project was appropriate for Teamwork aid; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: An application for assistance under the teamwork scheme was submitted by the organisation “Network for Jobs” in April 1986. Because of the restrictions on Teamwork funds at the time, it was not possible to consider this application.

MainHeading.P: Following a meeting between representatives of the organisation and the Minister of State at my Department in May 1986 a further application was received from “Network for Jobs” in June 1986. After consideration of the application by the Teamwork Monitoring Committee in June 1986 discussions took place between the sponsoring group and officials of my Department in July 1986. In the course of these discussions further information on the application, including data on the five separate projects encompassed by it, was requested. This was received in August 1986. From an examination of the five proposals it appeared that four of these were essentially commercial in character and would not, therefore be eligible for consideration under Teamwork. Further evidence of the commercial nature of these four projects was evidenced by the fact that they were approved for planning grants under the youth employment agency's community enterprise programme. This programme is designed to assist projects which may be sustainable on a commercial basis. The applicants were notified accordingly on 10 September 1986. The fifth application submitted was examined but it did not meet the criteria for Teamwork and the applicants were notified accordingly on 17 September 1986.

A complaint about my Department's handling of the case was made to the Ombudsman on behalf of “Network for Jobs”. The Ombudsman did not uphold the complaint and the group was informed of the decision by letter dated 11 May 1987.

asked the Minister for Health if he will review the procedures for the storing of diaconol and palfium so that local pharmacists do not have to take more than they require for an individual patient and to allow them to withdraw only the specific amount they need and thus reduce the risk of robbery and violent attacks; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: It is accepted practice in the case of all controlled drugs and more particularly with synthetic opiates like those mentioned by the Deputy for pharmacists to retain minimum stocks of such drugs. Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he intends proceeding with the planned Sligo General Hospital extension; if so when construction work will commence; the amount of money allocated for work this year; the length of time it will take to complete the entire project; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.P: I accept the need for an extension to Sligo General Hospital and it is my intention to proceed with this project. The North-Western Health Board have received tenders for the proposed extension and the report on these tenders is currently being examined in my Department. This project is a major development with considerable capital funding implications and the question of the acceptance of tenders is being considered in the context of the capital funds that are now available and the expenditure requirements of this and all the other projects that are included in the health capital programme.

asked the Minister for Health in relation to the AIDS programme, the numbers who have been tested to date; the increases in the numbers presenting themselves for tests as a result of the education programme; the number of these who have been HIV positive; and if he has satisfied himself that resources are adequate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

It is still too early to determine the effect that the Public Information Programme on AIDS, launched earlier this month and now being carried out in each health board area, has had on HIV test figures. The Central Strategy Committee on AIDS, established under my Department, is continuing to monitor the situation and will recommend future action that will be required to combat the spread of the virus.

asked the Minister for Health the number of general practitioners who are regularly involved in the supply of services within our public and private hospitals; and if he foresees an increased role for general practitioners in hospitals in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

I do not currently see an increased role for general practitioners in the hospital area although an increasing number of such doctors may become involved at certain levels of the hospital service, for example, in general practitioner access schemes whereby groups of local GPs may provide services for patients in district hospitals under an agreement with the local health board.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Medical Service for Kidney Patients.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he has satisfied himself that the medical services for kidney patients in need of dialysis treatment are adequate in light of the sudden drop in kidney donors; the reason, if any, for the sudden reduction in the number of donors; if he will be involved in seeking to reverse the trend; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that the present renal dialysis services are adequate to meet the demand. The overriding considerations in relation to the procurement of human organs are the rights and wishes of the individual and the next of kin and these must be respected. The kidney donor campaign which is organised by the Irish Kidney Association and which I launched this year has, I think, been successful and has certainly increased public awareness of the need for kidney donors. I have consulted with the appropriate organisations and there is no clear indication of the reason for the drop in donations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recruitment of General Practitioners.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he intends restricting the entry of general practitioners to the general medical service scheme as part of the embargo on the public service, if he has established figures of general practitioners in the general medical service which he would see as an absolute ceiling; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The Minister for Finance in his budget statement on 31 March 1987 said that no vacancy within the Public Service may be filled without the express approval of the Minister concerned with the consent of the Minister for Finance.
In line with this decision on 23 April 1987 my Department issued instructions to health agencies in relation to the Government's decision on the non-filling of vacancies.

Essentially the decision to initiate a proposal to fill any vacancy in the choice of doctor scheme rests with health boards who will in making the decision to seek approval for such a course of action have regard to whether the filling of the vacancy is essential.

While no absolute ceiling for the number of general practitioner contractors in the GMS has ever been specified by the Department, there is clearly a practical limit to the number of doctors required to provide services under the GMS scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: As explained to the Deputy in response to previous representations, a special school transport service may be established and maintained only on condition that a minimum daily number of not less than ten eligible children from a distinct locality will avail regularly of the service to their nearest school. Since this requirement is not met in this case the Department has no authority to set up a special transport service to Lauragh national school for the children in question.
It is not open to the Department to pay a grant towards the cost of private transport arrangement for these children.
asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the major extension to Crinkle national school, County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed in principle to grant-aid the extension of Crinkle national school, County Offaly, and awaits a report from its professional officers on the feasibility of the proposals. My Department will communicate the outcome as soon as possible to the school authorities.

asked the Minister for Education when improvements will be carried out to Dangan national school, Kilmore, County Roscommon; if her attention has been drawn to the overcrowding at this school; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department are at present considering a report from their professional advisers on a proposed scheme of improvements to Dangan national school, County Roscommon, for which grant-aid has been sought. A decision on the matter will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible.

In March 1986 my Department sanctioned a grant towards the cost of providing a prefabricated classroom at the school, on the basis of the pupil enrolment figures available at that time. In the event, the pupils enrolments fell and the prefabricated classroom was not provided. In the light of the Deputy's question I am arranging for this aspect of the matter to be further investigated.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Education for Children with Behavioural Problems.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will clarify references she made recently with regard to the establishment of special projects for children with behavioural problems; the structures she envisages which would be most appropriate; and when she envisages the launching of such projects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed in principle to the provision of special measures on a pilot basis to cater for a very small minority of primary school children who are so disruptive that they seriously interfere with the working of schools and deny other children their rights to education. Appropriate arrangements for the continued education of such pupils are being examined at present in consultation with the interests concerned, but it is not possible to say, as yet, when the new measures will be introduced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the proposals, if any, she has to make grant-aid available to assist with the provision and development of an access road to the new primary school at Bohola, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department have no proposals to make grant-aid available to assist with the provision and development of an access road to the new primary school at Bohola, County Mayo. My understanding is that proposals in this matter are being considered by the local authority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will confirm that funding will continue for two full time youth workers with St. Michael's parish youth project at St. Michael's Estate, Inchicore, Dublin 8; if she is aware of the sensitivity and importance of this project (details supplied); and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The final allocation to my Department for the support of youth work and related services is still under review. I am fully aware of the sensitivity and importance of St. Michael's parish youth project but until a final decision is made on the allocation I am not in a position to say whether funding will continue for the employment of two youth workers with the project.
asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the proposed development at Carrig national school, County Tipperary; and when work is expected to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed in principle to grant-aid the proposed development at Carrig national school, County Tipperary. At present my Department await the completion of a feasibility study which has been sought as to how best the required development can be provided. I am not in a position at this stage to say when works may be expected to commence.
asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the VEC community college in Seán McDermott Street, Dublin 1; when tenders will be approved; and when work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The preliminary tender report in relation to this project has been examined and found satisfactory by my Department.
To determine when the project may proceed further, through the issue of authorisation to prepare the final tender report, this case must be reviewed in the context of the capital resources available.
It is not possible at this stage to indicate when construction work will begin.

asked the Minister for Education when sanction will issue for the erection of a playground shelter at Innishannon national school, County Cork; if a grant will be paid towards the construction of same; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: It is not my Department's practice to grant-aid the provision of playground shelters in national schools by way of supplementary site works.

asked the Minister for Education if she has allocated the £3.15 million received to-date from the National Lottery to youth and sporting organisations; the amount given to each section and organisation; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The allocation of grants to youth and sports organisations from the sum of £3.15 million received from National Lottery proceeds is under consideration in my Department at present.
I shall make an announcement in this regard in the near future.
asked the Minister for Education if money will be provided this year for the extension to Rathcormac national school, County Sligo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Because of the extent to which my Department's capital allocation for the national schools building programme had already been committed prior to my assuming office, I think it unlikely that grant moneys will be available this year for the proposed extension to Rathcormac national school, County Sligo.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Repeat Leaving Certificate Courses.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has issued a directive to the managers of secondary schools that leaving certificate pupils will not be allowed to repeat this exam; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I have not issued a directive to that effect.

Under the terms of Circular Letter M85/85 schools may apply for sanction to provide repeat leaving certificate courses. The applications received in respect of the coming school-year are being considered at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. Kitt Mr. T. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the necessary temporary accommodation, in the form of prefabricated structures, will be provided for the pupils and teachers of Divine Word national school, Marley Grange, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to the reply which I gave on 5 May 1987 to a previous question about the accommodation problem at the Divine Word national school, Marley Grange, County Dublin. A decision has not yet been reached on the form in which the extra accommodation sought is to be provided.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Summerhill North (Cork) School Project.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will sanction the opening in September 1987 of the Cork school project (details supplied) at Summerhill north, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: An examination of the application form the Cork School Project for sanction to establish a multi-denominational primary school in Cork city is nearing completion in my Department. A decision will be conveyed to the promoters of the project as soon as possible.

asked the Minister for Education if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the F.C.J. sisters, Laurel Hill, County Limerick have submitted drawings to her Department in relation to a proposal to convert one of their dormitary blocks to secondary school accommodation, that these drawings which have now reached stage 5 were submitted in January 1987; and if she will expedite the process whereby this conversion receives approval to go to tender in view of the delay involved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The bills of quantities for this project have been completed and are satisfactory. The next stage is the invitation of tenders. To determine when the project may proceed further, through the issue from my Department of authorisation to seek tenders, this case must be reviewed in the context of the capital resources available.
asked the Minister for Education the reason for the delay in approving the application for a new national school building at Athenry, County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: A grant was sanctioned in January 1987 towards the cost of a new national school building at Athenry, County Galway, following earlier preparation of sketch plans for the project. One of the outstanding matters which precluded the earlier sanction of the grant was the necessity to have the title of the proposed site for the new building cleared by the Chief State Solicitor. There has been no avoidable delay in processing the planning of this project.

asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the proposed extension to Commons national school, Killybegs, County Donegal; the present stage of the development; the extra accommodation being provided; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Working drawings for a new national school at Commons, Killybegs, County Donegal are being prepared. The proposal is to grant aid the provision of four classrooms, a general purposes area and the usual ancillary accommodation.

asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the proposed extension to Fintra national school, Killybegs, County Donegal; if she will outline details of the extra accommodation being provided; the present stage of planning; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: The extra accommodation approved in principle to be grant aided in connection with the extension of Fintra national school, County Donegal, comprises two classrooms, a general purposes area and certain ancillary areas. Plans have been approved on that basis and preparation of the working drawings is in hands.

A review of enrolments at the school is currently being undertaken with a view to determining whether the recent decline in the number of pupils attending the school may warrant a revision of scheme. The outcome of this review will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Allocation for the Building of Schools.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the allocation this year towards the building of post-primary schools, vocational schools, community schools, comprehensive schools and other schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to the Book of Estimates for the current year, where the information sought by him is available.
